TIME — MIDNIGHT.</br>Chequ'ring with silver rays the gloom of night,</br>The Moon majestic shed her gentle light;</br>When sad beneath a sable shade reclin'd,</br>With love-sick lays two shepherds charm'd the wind.</br>In mournful mood by turns they told their woes,</br>Spending in grief the time of still repose.
First Cannon sung — his love with scorn repaid,</br>Thus hope and sad despair his strains alternate sway'd.

"Come lovely Norah, charm my ravish'd sight,</br>And add to former transports fresh delight;</br>Disdainful fair — too beauteous in your face!</br>Ah why should scorn your beauteous looks disgrace?</br>No more in ringlets let me twine my hair,</br>No more sweet violets in my bosom wear;</br>No more my form in each bright fountain view,</br>Since Norah scarce esteems it worth her view.</br>Yet yield not fair one to illusive arms,</br>But bless a faithful lover with your charms;</br>Desirous flames still glow within my soul</br>And all my actions, all my thoughts controul;</br>With love I pine — love melts my soul away,</br>Come charming fair, this burning anguish stay;</br>Soft spring renews with green the rural bow'rs,</br>And cloaths in blooming pomp the balmy flow'rs.</br>The sun bids winter's ruffian storms to fly,</br>Melodious birds in nature's music vie;</br>Then haste and let us tread each verdant field,</br>To cull the sweets which Flora's bounties yield;</br>Come scornful nymph — no youth can offer more</br>Than the fair gifts I keep for you in store:</br>For you the Linnet prunes its golden wing,</br>The birds I rear for you in concert sing;</br>But now their notes my soul no longer charm,</br>For ah, your frowns my joys of life disarm,</br>My bees for you from rose to rose shall stray,</br>And each desert shall honied sweets display.</br>When autumn's riches feast the toiling swain,</br>What ripen'd fruits shall glow your taste to gain.</br>Few gardens can with mine in beauty vie</br>Blest by the favours of a southern sky:</br>My tender lambs that us'd to sport and play,</br>Fed by your hand no more — no more are gay.</br>But if your all reviving form appear,</br>Their sports again my pleasant meads shall chear;</br>Your favour'd doves again shall playful coo,</br>And the proud turkey boast his splendid hue.—</br>But whither wanders my distracted brain?</br>Unfeeling Norah glories in my pain:</br>And all my rural presents will disdain!

Some favour'd youth delighted with her charms,</br>She clasps enamour'd in her faithless arms;</br>While left a prey to cruel pangs of love,</br>With strains of sad despair I fill the grove.</br>Ah cease, ill-fated Cannon — cease to mourn,</br>Hopeless for love that never will return!</br>Farewell false Norah — since your faithful swain,</br>Finds all attempts to melt your heart in vain;</br>Farewell — to yonder rock that meets the sky</br>With frantic haste will wretched Cannon fly,</br>Plunge in the flood that deep beneath it flows</br>And put a fatal period to his woes.—</br>Then cease my muse!" — with heart-felt anguish stung,</br>Such lays as those dejected Cannon sung.
But far more sad were wretched Dillon's pains,</br>Soothing the silent night with mournful strains.

"Come Muse, (he cried) in plaintive mood resound,</br>The woes which Dillon's soul with anguish wound;</br>On Ellin's sacred grave sad dirges breathe,</br>While soft I deck it with a sable wreath.</br>Ah lovely nymph, and are your beauties fled,</br>Say are you mingled with the pallid dead;</br>Tho' nipt so soon your bloom of life is past,</br>Still shall my love to you unfading last.</br>Still shall your shade my pensive sorrows know,</br>Still shall your manes listen to my woe.</br>And oft as now while Cynthia's silver horn,</br>Glides thro' the clouds, I'll kiss your grave forlorn.</br>My promis'd bride! — and has malignant death,</br>Suck'd the sweet perfume of your vi'let breath?</br>Alas!  that he should dare our love to scorn,</br>To mock the transports of our nuptial morn!</br>Was it for him all shepherds call'd you fair?</br>For him with roseate wreaths I deck'd your hair</br>Did nymphs for him your bridal dress prepare?

Ah did the blooming rose and lilly vie</br>Refulgent on your cheeks for him to die?</br>Oh torture — torture — let me call to mind</br>That fatal morn when to the future blind,</br>Joyful I led you thro' the crowded way,</br>Blushing with sweetness like the rising day;</br>The brightest gems that southern mines cou'd prize,</br>Vied not in lustre with your dazzling eyes;</br>Love smil'd among your dimples, aim'd his darts,</br>From your sweet looks to pierce the coldest hearts.</br>But then your shape majestic and divine,</br>Each gazing shepherd envied you were mine!</br>Yet when my heart beat high to loves alarms</br>When close I prest you in my fervent arms,</br>Cold — sunk  your beauties from my fond embrace,</br>While sudden death made pale your lovely face:</br>My love — my Dillon — breathing slow you cry'd</br>Then gently bow'd your lovely head and dy'd.—</br>Oh what a scene was this — and do I live,</br>Does wretched Dillon such a fate survive?</br>From the dear charmer of his fancy torn,</br>The joys of life are now become his scorn.</br>With grief I fade, with hidden anguish pine,</br>Soon shall my corse, sweet Ellen, sleep by thine;</br>Then every rural nymph and swain shall say,</br>As chance by this ill-fated grove they stray,</br>'Beneath this turf, interr'd, lies side by side,</br>A faithful shepherd with his charming bride!'"—</br>
